metadata.title: Convert Nautical Miles to Kilometers – Length Converter
metadata.description: Convert distances from nautical miles to kilometers using the exact international definition of the nautical mile adopted by hydrographic and standards organizations.

introduction: Convert nautical miles to kilometers instantly using the internationally agreed definition of the nautical mile, so your figures match modern nautical charts and flight planning documents.
The international nautical mile is defined as exactly 1852 meters, which corresponds to 1.852 kilometers, and this converter uses that exact factor for every calculation.
This makes the tool suitable for mariners, pilots, oceanography students, and engineers who need distances expressed in both traditional navigation units and SI-based kilometers.
methodology: The calculator applies the internationally adopted definition of the nautical mile: 1 nautical mile = 1852 meters. This definition was set at the 1929 International Hydrographic Conference and is documented in standards literature and NIST guidance on non-SI units.

Because 1 kilometer is exactly 1000 meters, the conversion factor from nautical miles to kilometers is 1.852. The calculator multiplies the input value in nautical miles by 1.852 to obtain the distance in kilometers.
Mathematically, the forward conversion is: kilometers = nautical miles × 1.852. The inverse relationship, used in the companion calculator, is: nautical miles = kilometers ÷ 1.852.

The underlying definition of the nautical mile is linked to the Earth's geometry: one nautical mile corresponds to one minute of arc (1/60 of a degree) of latitude along a meridian on an idealized Earth. Modern standards fix this historical value at exactly 1852 meters to ensure consistency across charts and navigation systems.

Internally, the converter assumes that your inputs are already in international nautical miles, not in obsolete variants such as the former U.S. or Admiralty nautical miles. All displayed results are in decimal kilometers; any rounding or trimming of decimal places in external reports should follow your organization's reporting conventions and applicable technical standards.
examples: A coastal passage of 35 nautical miles: 35 × 1.852 = 64.82 kilometers. The converter returns 64.82 km, which you can round to 64.8 km or 65 km depending on your charting practice.
A medium-range flight segment of 420 nautical miles: 420 × 1.852 = 777.84 kilometers. This lets you align navigation distances with performance data and fuel planning tables expressed in SI units.

A short training leg of 8 nautical miles for a sailing class: 8 × 1.852 = 14.816 kilometers. In many teaching contexts, this may be reported as 14.8 km or 14.82 km, but the underlying factor remains exactly 1.852.
summary: This converter uses the exact international definition 1 nautical mile = 1.852 kilometers, as adopted by hydrographic and metrology organizations, to deliver consistent, standards-based results.
Use it whenever you need to present navigation distances in SI units, cross-check route lengths from charts, or document voyages and flights in kilometers while still planning in nautical miles.

glossary.definition: A unit of length used primarily in marine and air navigation, defined as exactly 1852 meters and historically corresponding to one minute of arc of latitude.
The SI unit of length commonly used for land distances and scientific work, defined as exactly 1000 meters.
A unit of speed equal to one nautical mile per hour; not directly converted in this tool but based on the same definition of the nautical mile.
The shortest path between two points on the surface of a sphere; nautical miles and knots are widely used because they relate naturally to great-circle navigation on the Earth.

faqs.question: What exact formula does this nautical miles to kilometers converter use?
faqs.answer: The converter uses the international definition 1 nautical mile = 1852 meters. Since 1 kilometer = 1000 meters, the factor between nautical miles and kilometers is 1.852. The calculation is kilometers = nautical miles × 1.852, with no approximation in the factor itself.

faqs.question: Where does the value 1 nautical mile = 1.852 kilometers come from?
faqs.answer: The value was adopted at the 1929 International Hydrographic Conference as the international nautical mile and is documented by standards bodies such as NIST and in SI-related reference material. It replaces earlier national definitions that differed by a few meters and ensures that nautical charts and navigation data are consistent worldwide.

faqs.question: How accurate are the results from this converter for real-world navigation?
faqs.answer: The conversion factor 1.852 is exact by definition, so the limiting factors in practice are your input accuracy, rounding choices, and the precision of your underlying route geometry or GNSS fixes. For voyage planning, flight logging, and academic work, this level of precision is fully consistent with modern hydrographic and aeronautical standards.

faqs.question: When should I work in nautical miles instead of kilometers?
faqs.answer: Nautical miles are standard in marine and air navigation because they relate directly to the Earth's latitude grid and pair naturally with knots as a speed unit. Kilometers are often preferred in engineering calculations, environmental reporting, and documents that must be fully SI based. This converter lets you move between the two representations without changing the underlying distance.

faqs.question: Does this tool convert statute miles or knots as well?
faqs.answer: No. This calculator is dedicated to converting distances from nautical miles to kilometers. To convert statute miles to kilometers or to convert between knots and kilometers per hour, use specialized converters so that each step uses the correct definition and avoids compounding rounding errors.

faqs.question: Is the nautical mile an SI unit?
faqs.answer: The nautical mile is not an SI unit, but it is recognized in international guidance as a specialized unit accepted for use in navigation. The definition itself is expressed in SI base units, and organizations such as NIST and BIPM describe its relationship to the meter for consistency in scientific and technical work.

faqs.question: Can I rely on this converter for safety-critical or legal navigation decisions?
faqs.answer: The conversion factor used here is the same as that referenced in official standards, but safe navigation and regulatory compliance always depend on authoritative sources such as up-to-date nautical charts, aviation publications, and your organization's operating procedures. Use this tool as a convenient aid, not as a substitute for certified navigation instruments and official documentation.
